title: Counting From a Percentage Slice
problem_text: A pie chart represents the favourite fruits of 240 students. The slice for **Apples** covers 25 % of the chart. How many students chose Apples?
common_pitfalls: Dividing 240 by 25 instead of multiplying by 0.25.

title: Converting Angle to Percentage
problem_text: In a pie chart the **Science** sector has an angle of 72°. What percentage of the whole set chose Science?

title: Fraction Slice to Quantity
problem_text: In a pie chart showing 150 coloured marbles, the **Red** slice occupies \(\tfrac{1}{5}\) of the circle. How many red marbles are there?
common_pitfalls: Multiplying by 5 instead of dividing by 5.

title: Angle to Simplest Fraction
problem_text: A sector for **IT** jobs in a careers survey has an angle of 126°. Express this portion as a fraction of the whole circle in its simplest form.
solution_hints: Reduce the fraction to lowest terms.
common_pitfalls: Cancelling only by 2 instead of the highest common factor.

title: Angle Needed for Votes
problem_text: In a school election, Candidate B received 90 of the 300 votes cast. What angle would represent Candidate B on a pie chart?
common_pitfalls: Multiplying 90 by 360 directly (forgetting to divide by total first).

title: Finding Quantity From Angle
problem_text: A survey pie chart of 200 people shows **Travel** with an angle of 45°. How many people chose Travel?

title: Percentage From Count
problem_text: In a pie chart of 120 pupils’ favourite sports, 18 pupils prefer **Swimming**. What percentage does the Swimming slice represent?
common_pitfalls: Leaving the answer as a fraction.

title: Angle Relationship (Double)
problem_text: In a sports participation pie chart, the sector for **Basketball** is **twice** as large as the sector for **Tennis**, which measures 30°. What is the angle for Basketball?

title: Angle for a Quarter Slice
problem_text: A reading survey shows that \(\tfrac{1}{4}\) of pupils enjoy **Mystery** books. What is the angle of the Mystery sector on the pie chart?
common_pitfalls: Using 360 ÷ 4 = 45° (mix-up with half of a half).

title: Total Quantity From a Sector
problem_text: On a company pie chart, the **Marketing** sector is 54° and represents 60 employees. How many employees are there in the whole company?
